An aetiological approach to be carried out in parallel with the implementation of treatment.

Aetiological orientation is based on the systems affected (central or peripheral motor impairment, sensory impairment, cognitive impairment), the age of onset of the disorders (antenatal/neonatal/post-natal), and their course (stability, improvement, regression).

A distinction must be made between genetic causes (malformations, chromosomal or gene abnormalities, etc.) and accidental causes (perinatal anoxia, cranial trauma, meningitis, etc.).

Depending on the diagnostic hypotheses, brain imaging (MRI), genetic tests and electroencephalograms may be carried out.

question.title: What is the primary approach used to determine the cause of disability?
question.description: A multiple-choice question about aetiological orientation

option_a.title: Aetiological orientation
option_a.description: A systematic approach to identifying the cause of disability

option_b.title: Diagnostic hypotheses
option_b.description: The process of forming a list of possible causes of a disability

option_c.title: Treatment implementation
option_c.description: The process of providing care and support to individuals with disabilities

option_d.title: Brain imaging
option_d.description: A diagnostic tool used to visualize the brain and its structures

correct_option.title: A
correct_option.description: The correct letter of the answer option
